awd_titl_txt: RoL: EAGER: DESYN-C3 Enzyme cascades in synthetic membraneless organelles
awd_abstract_narration:
Like factories, cells organize processes by placing them in distinct rooms (organelles). The project will create a model system to understand how cells utilize compartments without distinct walls. Design rules for the formation and function of these compartments will be established. The rules will be tested by constructing an membraneless organelle that houses enzymes that direct a series of reactions. The project will also focus efforts to foster a diverse STEM workforce through student recruiting, training, and teaching at all levels. Graduate and undergraduate students will be recruited. Outreach activities on enzymes will be developed for middle school students and summer research experiences will be provided to local high school students.

Membraneless organelles (M-organelles) provide spatial and temporal organization through selective phase separation. They are important in cell signaling, transcriptional control, and stress response. However, a robust model system that replicates their function does not yet exist. This project will develop a model system based on electrostatically driven liquid-liquid phase separation of enzymes. A model enzyme cascade of glucose oxidase and horseradish peroxidase will be incorporated into these synthetic M-organelles. Protein engineering of the enzymes will be used to determine the design rules for multiple protein partitioning. A library of fluorescent fusion proteins will be biosynthesized and their incorporation in the synthetic M-organelles will be quantified by fluorescence microscopy. The development of these design principles will enable control over the relative ratio of the sequenced enzymes in the synthetic M-organelles. Importantly, the impact of the synthetic M-organelle microenvironment on the efficiency of the enzyme cascade will be evaluated. The spatial distribution of the enzymes, substrates, and product will be monitored and used to determine detailed reaction kinetics. These combined efforts will help to establish rules for the formation and function of M-organelles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Cells organize their contents through the formation of distinct environments, called organelles. It has recently been discovered that one type of organelle does not have a physical barrier (like a cellular door or wall) that creates this environment, these organelles are called membraneless organelles. This project worked to develop synthetic versions of these membraneless organelles. Using two model systems we have identified design criteria for the formation of synthetic membraneless organelles in a test tube and key features that impact reproducibility of in vitro measurements of activity. The first model system used colored proteins to easily quanitfy the formation of membraneless organelles. Using this model system, we have identified how the overall charge and pattern of charges affect protein incorporation in these synthetic compartments. The second model system used enzymes (proteins that perform chemical reactions) with colored products. In the process of incorporating these enzymes in the synthetic membraneless organelles we discovered challenges with reproducibility that impacted our studies, and likely those of others as well. We identified that small amounts of contaminants in the starting chemicals are the cause of the reproducibility issues and have determined an approach to avoid this challenge going forward. 

This project has provided research training opportunities for high school, undergraduate, and graduate students as well as for a postdoctoral scholar. These trainees got experience in experimental design, data analysis, modelling, and data presentation. In addition to this primary research training, engagement with diverse middle school students from New York City was achieved through the development of outreach activities and through interactive lab tours and presentations. This project has also enabled the updating of a biochemical engineering elective course, which has helped prepare undergraduate and graduate students for the modern STEM workforce through a new focus on synthetic biology, recombinant proteins, and vaccine production. Each of these activities has had an impact on the development of talented and diverse student population, ready to enter the STEM workforce in the biotechnology sector.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: Allie Obermeyer
